Line: Yeah.

Episode: Put Your Head on My Shoulders
Line: I guess so. [Bender laughs and puts his arms around Fry and Leela and pats them.] Watch the neck! Watch the neck!

Episode: Put Your Head on My Shoulders
Line: My ass! My beautiful ass!

Episode: Put Your Head on My Shoulders

Line: Good news, everyone. I've taught the toaster to feel love. [The toaster bounds across the table, barking like a dog and licks Bender. He knocks it away and it hits the wall. Toast springs out of it.] And Hermes returns from his vacation today.
[monotonous] Good morning, people.
Hey, Hermes!
Hello!
Good to see you.
Yo!
My man!
So how was the Spleef Nebula?
[monotonous] The flight had a stopover on the Brain Slug Planet. Hermes liked it so much he decided to stay of his own free will.
Hermes has all the fun. Wait a second! He's got a Brain Slug on his head!
[whispering] Shh! You're gonna get us all assimilated!
[whispering] Just act normal and switch to a garlic shampoo.
[monotonous] On to new business. Today's mission is for all of you to go to the Brain Slug Planet.
What are we going to do there?
[monotonous] Just walk around not wearing a helmet.
Sounds great, Hermes! Whatever you say. [He nods and then leans in to the others.] [whispering] Let's ditch him and go to the movies!
Hey, yeah!
I'm seeing a movie with friends!
Cool! Let's see this one!
Nah. I'm not in the mood for a historical documentary. I've heard good things about Quizblorg, Quizblorg.
Guk! I hate subtitles. Alien films are so pretentious.

Fellows! Fellows! How about a film we can all enjoy? Planet Of The Clams. [He points to the films poster that parodies Planet Of The Apes except with Decapodians and bipedal clams riding bareback on horses.] It's about an upside-down world where lobster is slave to clam.
Who invited you? Let's just see All My Circuits  The Movie.
Yeah, I wanna see that.
Good point, Bender.
I'll take a small Slurm.
For only 25 cents less, you can get a super-small.
Uh, OK. [The robot puts a tiny cup under the machine and it fills with a drip. Fry takes it and walks away. He trips and it spills onto his shirt.] Oh, man!
Hey, gimme a large diet malt liquor and a popcorn with extra motor oil.
Down in front!
[voice-over; on screen] Glagnar's Human Rinds presents  This Week In The Universe.
[sarcastic] Ooh, this is real futuristic!
Shh! Don't talk during the movie.

[voice-over; on screen] This week in the universe  New New York mayor C. Randall Poopenmeyer opens a new tube line to alleviate rush hour traffic. [In the movie, Poopenmeyer cuts a ribbon across a tube and the picture switches to people packed into another tube. The picture switches again to an alien army show.] Dateline  Paramecium Homeworld. Newly-crowned Miss Universe Gladice Lennox entertains troops fighting to wipe out the human race. [The soldiers cheer.] Go get 'em, boys! [The scene changes to a wrestling ring.] And in the world of Ultimate Robot Fighting, the Masked Unit wins his championship bout against Gorgeous Gonks by technical melting.
[shouting] Go, Masked Unit! [A tall robot and a wide Fembot sit in front of him. The robot blocks his view.] Uh, hey, buddy! Yo! [He whistles.] You mind taking your head off?
I'm sorry, sir, but I need it to watch the movie.
Just ask Flabby over here to describe it to you later.
Sir, she is as the factory made her.
Well they should have stopped making her about halfway through.
[in movie] Whee!
[in movie] Well, that finishes this paperwork. [The phone rings and he picks it up.] Calculon Enterprises.
[on screen; in movie] Calculon, a fight scene has broken out at the special effects warehouse. Come quickly before a fiery explosion chases someone down a hallway.
[in movie] I have no choice but to--
[voice-over; in movie] If you want Calculon to race to the laser gun battle in his hover-Ferarri, press 1. If you want Calculon to double-check his paperwork, press 2. Enter now.
You have pressed 2.
No, I didn't!
I'm almost positive you did.
[in movie] Add in the carryover from form 16A, then deduct line 2B...
Pardon me, sir, but you seem to be inadvertently kicking my seat.
[mocking] "Pardon me, sir, but you seem to be bleh, bleh..."
Yes, that's the gist of what I said. Would you mind?
Sure thing, pal.
Uh, sir?
[fake shocked] Who threw that?
That's it! Sir, I challenge you to fisticuffs!
Oh, I'm boned.
Let's all go to the lobby!
I'm gonna open a file of whup-ass on you!
Bender, do you know who that was?
Cripes! The Masked Unit! You knocked him out cold.
I'm impressed.
Son, I'm the commissioner of Ultimate Robot Fighting. I'm a connoisseur of jerks like you who pick fights in movie theatres and you're the biggest I've ever seen.
You should see me at funerals.
Kid, I want you in the Ultimate Robot Fighting League.
Ultimate Robot Fighting? Sounds pleasant! I'll do it.
My hero!
Aw. They don't make movies like this anymore.
I'm gonna be the greatest Ultimate Robot Fighter ever. Float like a floatbot, sting like an automatic stinging machine!
Bender, you can't be an Ultimate Robot Fighter. It's the most brutal form of competition in the galaxy!
It is?
There are no rules. Two robots enter, one robot leaves. Then later the other robot leaves after being declared the winner.
Well, that doesn't sound so bad.
Oh, did I mention the crippling, agonising pain? I'm pretty sure I did. Oh, yes, definitely.
Crippling pain? That's not covered by my insurance fraud! Count me out.
No! You've got to do it. I don't care how suicidal it is.
Hey! How come when I wanna do fun stuff that'll kill me you're against it?
This is more important than that marble-eating contest, Fry! It's about pride. Let me tell you a story from my childhood.
Oh, again with the orphanarium!
When I was growing up at the orphanarium, I got picked on a lot.
[voice-over] My only outlet was Arcturan Kung Fu.
Excellent. Bill, Keith, you will go to Junior Championships. Bill, congratulate Keith when he regains consciousness.
But, Master Fnog, I can beat these dorks with one eye closed.
Perhaps. But there is more to winning than beating your opponent. You lack the will of the warrior.
What do you mean? Watch this!
[crying] Ow!
No girl has the will of a warrior. You have the will of a housewife or, at best, the schoolmarm.
That's it. I'll take you on right now.
Very well. But, you see, I have the will of the warrior. Therefore, the battle is already over. The winner? Me! [He laughs.] Rematch? You lose again! Had enough? I thought so!
I lost my chance to be a champion. I won't let you throw away yours.
Leela's right! I don't wanna end up a loser like her. Count me back in!
Let's see what you got. Touch your toes.
Still ... can't ... reach!
Let's commence preparations for rumbling!

Ladies and gentlemen and smizmars, welcome to tonight's main event. In this corner, from Mom's Friendly Robot Factory in America's heartland, Mexico  Bender! [Bender holds up an "Applause" sign and the crowd cheers.] And in this corner, from and made of Parts Unknown  The Clearcutter!
[shouting] Bender rules!
[monotonous] I got you an official Bender hat.
Wow! Thanks, Hermes! [He raises it to his head.] I-- Hey! Cut that out!
You can't hit what you can't see!

Get up, Bender. You can't quit every time you get an axe in the back. [The Clearcutter drags him away from her, drills something and slams him back down again. There is now a hole in Bender's head.] Or a drill through your face. Now quit scratching your axe-hole and get out there.
Huh?
And the winner is ... Bender!
Nice work out there, kid.
Y'know, I think I he might be dead. I took a life!
Hi, boss. Yo, dude!
Hey, he's not dead. What's up with that?
What, you didn't read the pamphlet? Ultimate Robot Fighting's a scam, kid. It's rigged. [Bender gasps.] It's a secret, so keep it under your head, but the most popular robot always wins.
You mean I'm not a great fighter? I just won 'cause I'm popular?
Bingo!
Woo-hoo! I'm popular!
In fact, you're more than popular, you're pure lowest common denominator.
Go Bender! Go Bender! Go Bender!
Presenting Bender the Offender!
I'm just an ex-con trying to go straight and get my kids back.
Versus ... Billionairebot!
Versus  The Foreigner!
I'm not from here! I have my own customs! Look at my crazy passport!
Versus ... The Chain Smoker!
I love smoking. And after I win the fight I'm heading straight to your favourite restaurant.
You know, I'm also an Ultimate Robot Lover.
Bender! You're three hours late. You can't give up on your training now after both of us worked so hard.
What do you mean, "we"?
I said "us".
Hey, Bender the Offender doesn't need you. Bender the Offender doesn't need anybody!
What about us, Mr. The Offender?
Well obviously I need floozies! Let's roll!
Howdy, chief. For my next bout, what do you say I fight these two bimbos in some mud?
Actually, we've decided to go in a different direction.
What if I told your we wouldn't be fighting in the conventional sense?
Bender, your popularity is slipping.
Sales of your Bender Brand French milk bath soaps are down 20%.
Those morons! I said pea berry, not sandalwood!
Damnit, Bender! If you can't move sandalwood, you don't belong in this league! That's why you're gonna lose next week's title match.
But the crowd loves me.
Perhaps. But let's see how they feel about your new persona  The Gender Bender.
You'll be the most unpopular robot fighter since Sergeant Faeces Processor.
Oh, yeah? [He throws down the tutu.] Well what if I don't let the new guy win?
Then he'll just have to beat you the old-fashioned way  To death! [He presses an intercom button.] Melissa, send in the new kid.
I am Destructor!
[squeaky] See you at the fight.
So then I said, "See you at the fight." And that's the story.
Man, I thought Ultimate Robot Fighting was real, like pro wrestling. But it turns out it's fixed, like boxing.
It's one thing to win a fixed fight; there's dignity in that. But to lose? And in this atrocity? I can't do it! Leela, you gotta train me to win.
No way! If you wouldn't take my help when you didn't need it, why should I give it to you now when you do need it?
What the hell are you talking about?
I don't know. But I'm not helping.
[voice-over; on TV] You loved him as Bender the Offender! Now get ready to hate him as he threatens your sexuality in his new persona ... The Gender Bender!
[girly; on TV] I'm a real toughie!
[voice-over; on TV] Squaring off this Sunday versus Destructor!
[on TV] I will destroy you! [He hangs up then picks up again.] And stop calling me!
[on TV] I am Destructor's trainer, Master Fnog. My pupil will be victorious for he has the will of a warrior!
Not Fnog! Bender, let's hit the gym. I'm gonna teach you to fight like a girl!
[determined] I'll put on my tutu!

Hello and welcome to a remarkable championship bout. Destructor, a robotic armoured tank, whose very use at battle has been ruled a war crime, versus Gender Bender, who wears a pink tutu. [Hermes, his Brain Slug, Fry and Leela are in Bender's corner.] This is Rich Little, imitating Howard Cosell, here at ringside with George Foreman. George, a word in edgewise?
This could be the most one-sided fight since 1973 when Ali faced an 80-foot tall mechanical Joe Frazier. M-My memory's not what it used to be but I think the entire Earth was destroyed.
Interesting, if true. The Vegas odds tonight stand at an unprecedented 1000-0; a bet of $0 on Bender pays $1000 if he wins. Still, very few takers.
It's not-not a smart bet.
According to the script, you're supposed to prance out and tickle him with your fairy wand. Instead, I want you to prance out and kick his head off!
Got it. Large kickle, hold the tickle!
Thank God I'm free of that nightmare!
Sorry, buddy. Here you go!
[monotonous] Thank you. It was cold down there on the floor.
Here, Professor, I got you a programme.

Oh, good. Just let me put on my reading glasses. [He puts on some glasses with super-thick lenses and opens the programme. His lenses rip through it.] Why, Zoidberg, there's a lovely photo of you in here.
In this corner, the confused young robot with the golden curls. Weighing 525lbs  The Gender Bender!
Boo!
[shouting] Get that hippie out of the ring!
And in these two corners, weighing 400 tons, the gizmo from Pismo ... Beach, Destructor!
So, we meet again. Most amusing  Girl who acts like fighter training fighter who acts like girl.
Keep laughing, Fnog! [And he does. He walks back to his corner.] Ready, Bender?

I was born ready! Gimme the bell! [The bell dings.] Did you hear a noise? [Destructor punches him across the ring. Bender gets up and snaps his wand then hangs his tutu neatly on a coathanger inside his chest cabinet.] Final boarding call for flight 406, non-stop service to pain. [He kicks Destructor's shin but to no effect.] Now boarding standby passengers--
This seems like as good a time as any time to bring up my new grill for no reason. [Next to him, a grill grills five steaks.] With its patented design, the fat drains directly into my mouth.
[weakly] Fry! Throw in the towel! [He doesn't.] For God's sakes, Fry!
[monotonous] That's exactly what I was thinking.
[weakly] Mommy!
OK, Fnog, that's enough. Call him off. Fnog? [There is nothing but an antenna in Fnog's corner.] Hmm.
Why won't anyone help me?
So, once more we meet again.
Huh?
You didn't train Destructor. You're just controlling him like a puppet. I mean, cheating in a fake fight. That's low!
Better than being a girl. Like you. You're a girl!
[ironic] Oh, right. Girls lack the will of the warrior!
Huh? It's bendering time! [He throws some fake punches.] Take this. And this!
You were an excellent student. [Leela throws a punch but he grabs her wrist.] Too bad I was a lousy teacher!
I think you misunderstood the concept of "bendering time"!
See you in girl hell. I'll be in boy hell -- much nicer!
Yes!
Yes! [Destructor falls on him.] Oh!
And the winner is Destructor!
I've not seen a spectacle of this nature in all my years impersonating a sportscaster.
It sure was some fight. Interesting side note  As a head without a body, I envy the dead.
No argument here.
Bender? How did the fight go? I heard somebody got flattened!
Fry, where's your Brain Slug?
Poor little guy starved to death.
I'm proud of you, Bender. Sure, you lost. You lost bad. But the important thing is I beat up someone who hurt my feelings in high school.
I'm in tremendous pain here.
Great job, kid. You lost and you made it look almost half real. I want you to have this card good for 10% off at Bed Bath & Beyond.
Yes! I'm the greatest! The greatest!
And so ends the chronicle of one of the greatest ever to play the sport.
And he didn't look half bad in the tutu.
That he did surely not.
What?
Good news, everyone! Several years ago I tried to log on to AOL, and it just went through. Whee! We're online!
Go ahead, get into these net suits. I designed and tested them myself.
They smell like burning Rhesus Monkey.
Really? I guess when you're around it all day you stop noticing. Off you go.
Hey!
Behold  The Internet!
My God! It's full of ads!
Follow me!
It's immense.
It's got every piece of information anyone could ever want.
So I see!
What? What's going on here?
Hey, that's me!
No, it isn't. I just took some pictures of your face and stuck them on someone else's body.
Hey!
Are you over 18?
Yes.
Yes.
I'm telling you, Fry, they've got a chatroom for everybody. And here it is.
Ew, that is so gross!
Yeah. I'll stick with this one, thank you.
Yeah.
[sexfully] Hi, I'm a naughty nurse and I really need someone to talk to. $9.95 a minute.
Ooh, you're a dollar naughtier than most.
So how 'bout them Knicks?
Hello? Are there any girls in this room at all?
Yeah, bring on the hot chicks 'cause I'm a hot stud.
Yeah! So are we!

I'm a woman, if that's what you mean. [The nerds gasp.] I don't like to play games, so I'll just say I'm a cyclops, I'm a spaceship captain, I'm the only one of my species and I'm interested in meeting a man.
A woman! I'm scared.
Well, thanks to the Internet, I'm bored with sex. Is there a place on the web that panders to my lust for violence?
[sarcastic] Is the Space Pope reptilian?
Get ready for fun, Fry. Nowadays, we have a type of game played entirely on video.
We call it a "video game".
[sarcastic] Uh, "video game" you say? Well, golly gee, you mighty spacemen of the future will have to show me how it works.
The doctor is in! [Fry does a somersault and shoots at Zoidberg. He fizzles.] The doctor is out!

Everyone, please sign off. We have a delivery. Plus I have to use the phone-- [Bender shatters him and laughs. Leela jumps across a gap and runs up a wall, leaps from it and starts kicking Bender in the head. Farnsworth's head appears again.] Leela, please tell the others that--
Who are you?
I saw you in the chat room but you left before I had a chance to talk to you. After all these years of searching for another Cyclops.
I can't believe it. I've dreamed of this moment all my life.
Do you think perhaps you and I--

Fry, you idiot. Ever since I was abandoned on Earth I've been searching for who my people are and where they come from. Then I finally meet another Cyclops and you blast him. You wrecked my one chance to learn who I am!
Oh, Leela, I feel terrible. If there's anything I can ever do-- [He jumps out and shoots Leela.] Gotcha! [She shatters. Fry jumps up and down cheering.] I won! I'm the greatest!
Come on. We have work to do.
Are you still mad at me for wrecking your once-in-a-lifetime chance to learn the meaning of your existence?
No, I'm just happy you were able to win a video game. Now let's concentrate on getting this desperately-needed popcorn to the people of Cineplex 14, OK?
[voice-over; on screen] Leela, you've got mail! [Leela sighs.] It's not spam.
Huh? [She opens the email. The Cyclops appears on the screen.] It's him!
[on screen] To Leela. Subject  Hello. I am Alcazar. Fortunately I wrote down your screenname before I was dispatched by that oafish moron.
Kicked your ass!
[on screen] Leela, we have much to discuss. Please come join me on the planet of your birth. Co-ordinates follow.
Well, too bad we gotta make that urgent popcorn delivery.
It'll get there.
After a whole life of searching, I may finally have found where I belong.
Too bad it's a dump.
Look at that statue. It's only got one eye.
Lazy sculptor!
Welcome home, Leela.
Alcazar? [He leaps off the balcony and stands in front of her.] Are you real? Or am I seeing single?
Ow! Of course I'm real.
After all this time, somebody else with one eye who isn't a clumsy carpenter or, uh, a kid with a BB gun.

It's alright, Leela. You'll never be alone again. [He claps his hand and two lizards run out through an arch, pulling a carriage behind them.] Come, let me introduce you to yourself. Do you mind if your servants walk?
Not at all!
We are the last remaining Cyclopses. Our planet is Cyclopia. This is the capital, Cyclops City. Stop me if I'm going too fast for you.
There's so much information and yet somehow I feel as if I know it all already.
This sacred mosaic depicts our goddess of beauty.
Hmm, you got any sacred artwork of her from the back?
Her perfect eye reminds me of yours, Leela. Had our race survived, you would have been a temple priestess or a supermodel.
Oh, please! Really?
And there's the infamous pirate, Purple Beard, scourge of the six seas.
What's over that hill?
The Forbidden Valley. A holy sanctuary where no one may tread.
Is that anything like a cemetery 'cause I gotta take a leak. [Leela slaps him.] Ow!
Fry, that's offensive to our people. [She turns to Alcazar.] Isn't it?
Ow!
This is my home. I hope you don't think less of me because I live in a giant castle.
Oh, no, not at all. If anything, I'm more impressed.
Ooh! I'm gonna need to make some room.
In here is where I dream my lonely dreams and cook my simple meals.
It's all so sad. What happened to our people?
It's too painful to speak of now. Come, I'll show you your quarters.
Ow! Ow! Ow!
I heard you from my room. What's wrong?
Nothing. It's just-- No, Leela. I don't want to see tears in your perfect eye.
Please, is it about the fate of our people? Because I'm very interested in that.
Well, OK. But it's chilly and you're going to be all wet from the tears. Let's go into my chamber.

[voice-over] It wasn't long ago. Our people were happy and prosperous ... [The flashback cuts to a dark planet with rocky terrain and lots of large molehills.] ... but the eyeless mole people of Subterra 3 grew jealous of our visual prowess. They fired missile in all directions hoping to hit Cyclopia. [A mole man presses a button and several hundred missiles are launched from the planet.] Unfortunately, one of the 40 planets hit, was ours.
How far away do you think it is?
A trillion miles?
Things got hot. You look a little hot, actually. You can take off that jacket. [Leela takes her jacket off.] Our people don't like to be hot. Anyway, just before the impact...
[voice-over] Our smartest scientists managed to save one baby.
Alcazar, I used to be a baby, it might have been me!
[voice-over] Fortunately, I was employed as a pool cleaner at the time and, when I emerged from retrieving a dead possum, I found I was the only one left.
It's so tragic.
Yes, but the real tragedy is that our race ends with us.
It doesn't have to.
What do you mean?
You're a male and I'm a female.
I'm still not following you.
Wake up, my king.
Oh, jeez, what a night. Make me some coffee, would you.
Uh, sure, OK. What do you take with that?
Pancakes and sausage. Kitchen's in the basement, pans are in the attic.
Maybe after breakfast we can talk about rebuilding our civilisation.
Mmm! Great pancakes, Leela.

Yeah, they'll come in handy if I need to cover any tiny manholes. [He chuckles. Bender laughs loudly, scrapes his pancake onto the floor and slips the plate into his chest cabinet. Alcazar turns to Leela.] Listen, hon', we don't want to look like slobs in front of the other species, do we?
No.
So get to work on these dishes. And then organise my collection of naked celebrity photos by name and what you can see.
Look, Alcazar--
Call me Al.
Look, Al. I know you've been living alone a long time and I can sympathise, but I'm not your maid.
You're right, I'm sorry. I guess the relationship isn't going to work. So much for the Cyclops race. I thought it was a pretty good race but, uh--
OK, OK, I'll do the dishes. [She looks at the table but it has been cleared.] Hey, where'd they go?
Ah, Leela's experiencing the greatest joy a woman can feel  Worshipping some low-life jerk.
He may be some low-life jerk but I don't trust him. I think he's hiding something and I'm gonna find out what it is.
Try and stop me!
Al? I did my hair the way you wanted it. [She sits down next to him.] Who are these people?
Friends.
Hey, where'd you get this couch and that TV set and all this stuff?
They were giving it away on the street corner. Just like you, Leela!
Too bad they weren't giving away the three things you actually need  Mouthwash, a back wax and stain-proof underwear.
You go, girl!
By the way, your pal Fry fell into the dungeon. Take him a taco so he doesn't die and stink up the place.
Come on, Al, can't you let the little guy out?
Jeez, Leela, twice in one day? I'm not Superman!
Why were you sneaking into my people's forbidden valley?
'Cause I think Alcazar's hiding something from you. Listen, Leela, you may not like it, you may not believe it, you may not wanna hear it but Alcazar's a jerk. He's bad for you. He--
I know.
You do?
Fry, if it's obvious to you with your learning disability then of course it's obvious to me. He's crude and gross and he treats me like a slave.
Then dump his one-eyed ass.
I can't. If I leave Alcazar, that's the end of the Cyclops race. And I won't let that happen. Even if it means a lifetime of unhappiness.
[from bathroom] Leela! Mop up in aisle number two!
I'll break up with him at dinner.
I'll be there.
Yo, Leela, what gives? Pig says your slop tastes like crap.
Yeah. Like crap.
C'mon, Leela, you deserve better than this guy. Dump him already!
I'm trying.

Hey, everyone, jam a sock in your spit faucets. [Everyone stops eating and looks up.] Not long ago I spent my lonely nights renting slasher flicks with Rat Man and his girlfriend. But then a beautiful woman arrived and-- Stop eating, Pig! And she brought new hope for me and our once great civilisation. Now a million centuries of Cyclops destiny depend on the answer to one question. [He walks around the table to Leela and goes down on one knee.] Leela, will you marry me?
[whispering] No! No!
Yes! I will!
They're getting married!
Congratulations, Leela!
Hello.
Oh, this is great!
[shaking hands] Glad you could make it.
[shaking hands] It's a magical day.
[shaking hands] Welcome!
Psst, Leela. You've gotta get me out of here. It's horrible! Eating scraps, letting my waste drop wherever it falls like an animal in the zoo.
Animals go in the corner.
The corner! Why didn't I think of that?
Look, Fry, I'd like to help you but it's my wedding and I'm kind of busy. [She hands him a bottle.] Here. Try to be happy for me. That way at least one of us will be.
That's it! It's time for this bird to walk.
Bender, come on. We've gotta get some dirt on Alcazar. Let's go and find out what makes the Forbidden Valley so forbidden.
Uh, no, thanks. I'm good.
But there's probably some cool forbidden stuff you can steal.
I don't know, Fry. For the first time in my life I feel like I've stolen enough.
Bender, snap out of it!
Sorry, I don't know what came over me. Let's go. [He slings his sack of swag over his shoulder.] [singing] I love stealing, I love taking things!
[crying] That pig over there is wearing the same sandals as me.
Come on, boy, jump! [The lizards crash through the gate.] Good boy!
Whoa, Mittens!
My God! Four identical castles!
Each more identical than the last!
That's weird. It's another Cyclops, only this one has five eyes.
And here's another one with no eyes.
Does anyone have a reason why this couple shall not be joined in the irrevocable shackles of holy bliss?
Saving a race of one-eyed monsters? Who could object to that?
Cut to the chase, Preach!
Do you, Alcazar ... [Alcazar fast-forwards the Preacherbot.] ... [fast] take this woman before you ... to love ... in sickness ... do you part?
Yeah, sure I do. Come on, faster!
Do you, Leela, copy and paste his response till death do you part?
Oh, my God!
What the--?
Hey, Alcazar, you left somebody off the guest list.
Alcazar, why you are so late for our wedding? And why you have only one eye?

It ... ooh, uh! [He grows four more eyes.] Hey, sweetie. Just go back to the castle and wait for me. [He turns to Leela and returns to his one eye.] She-- She's nuts. I can morph into a five-eyed alien and I kinda said I'd marry her. But I'm really a Cyclops and I'm really going to marry you.
Oh, yeah? Then what about this?
This is a bit awkward.
Who's she?
Who's she?
Who are they?
Go back to the castle, Sandy.
And maybe you'd like to meet her. [A purple alien comes in.] And her.
Leela, this must all be very confusing.
A little. That's why I've decided to hurt you until you explain it.
Show us your real form!
Yeah!
Do it!

Well, this is the real me. But I can explain  We all have needs. Mine was to make it with five weirdos and have them scrub my five castles. I gave you all what you wanted and of course I made a few bucks letting Pig watch through the two-way mirror. Can any of you say you wouldn't have done the exact same thing in my position?
[crying] He's a saint!
But why did you have all five weddings on the same day?
Hey, lady, you got any idea what it costs to rent a tux that changes shape?
Alright, Alcazar, I just have one last question for you.
What's that?
If you can change form, why didn't you change it in the one place that counts?
Thanks for saving me from that creep, Fry.
Hey, that's what I do.
I guess I was so desperate to find out who I really was, I forgot who I really was.
No harm done. In the many decades you'll work to repay me for that shipment of popcorn you destroyed, you'll have plenty of time to search for your true home.
Yeah. I mean, how many planets can there be?
Good news, everyone! The university is bringing me up on disciplinary charges. Wait, that's not good news at all.
Whatever you did, Professor, I'm sure there's a reasonable explanation.
Yes, but they won't listen. Everyone's always in favour of saving Hitler's brain but when you put it in the body of a great white shark, ooh, suddenly you've gone too far.
Professor Farnsworth, do you know why we've called you here today?

Listen to me, you pompous frauds. If I'm going down, I'm taking you all with me. Dean Vernon, I know the truth  It was you driving your hover-car that night, not your horse. Dean Epsilon, I know all about your "Department of Pool Boy Studies". And Dr. Wernstrom ... Wernstrom!
Actually, Professor, we merely called you here to say... [The lights come on.] Surprise!
Surprise!
Happy birthday!
Surprise!
And you, Coach Smalley, or should I say "Coach hairpiece"?
No, Professor! It's a surprise party for your 150th birthday.
[muttering] Hundred and ... what? [He smiles.] Ooh!

Good evening, I'm-- [Feedback. He turns the knob on the side of his casing.] Whoa, sorry. I'm Bender and I'll be emceeing this roast. Y'know, they say you can judge a man by the company he keeps. So here's the Professor's oldest friend, a grotesque, stinking lobster.

Good evening, ladies and germs. [The band plays a rimshot.] That wasn't a joke, I was talking to Dean Streptococcus. [In the audience a big green germ waves.] Now, I'm not saying Professor Farnsworth is old, but if you consider his age, he's likely to die soon. [He grins. There is no rimshot and the audience don't laugh. A man drums his fingers on the table.] Hey, Ringo, that was the joke. Oh, it's Showtime at the Apollo all over again.

Where would the Professor be without students who love and respect him? Right there! [He points at Farnsworth and chuckles.] But seriously, of all the former crew members of the Professor's delivery ship, our next speaker is by far the most alive. Captain Musky?
I wouldn't wanna follow that guy!

And now, a man who needs no introduction. [He sits down and everyone looks around in confusion, Leela to her right and Zoidberg to the ceiling. Bender leans over to Fry.] [whispering] Fry, get up there!

Oh. [He takes the mic and the audience applauds.] Thank you. Y'know, when I was first asked to make a film about my nephew, Professor Farnsworth, I thought "Why should I?" Then later Leela made the film. But if I had made the film, you could bet there would have been a lot more topless women on motorcycles! [Farnsworth smiles.] Roll film!

[voice-over; in movie] Hubert J. Farnsworth was born April 9th 2851 in New New York's nerdiest slum, Hell's Laboratory. A precocious child, young Hubert learned to read while he was still in diapers -- at age 8. [A photo of young Farnsworth sitting reading a book on some steps in diapers appears on the screen.] And before long he blossomed into a greasy teenager.
[whispering] Dork alert!

[voice-over; in movie] After 14 years of graduate school, Farnsworth settled into the glamorous life of a scientist  Fast cars, trendy nightspots, beautiful women -- the Professor designed them all working out of his tiny, one-room apartment. [The pictures appear on a blackboard in his apartment.] For 50 years he worked at Mom's Friendly Robot Company, where he created the first robot capable of qualifying for a boat loan. [There is a short video clip of the robot buying its boat. The picture changes to Farnsworth tinkering with Bender's head.] And even as he nears his 150th birthday, the Professor retains the fiery passion of youth.
[in movie] Listen, you pompous frauds. If I'm going down, I'm taking you all with me.
How 'bout a few words, Professor?
Eh, wha?
I said "words".
Uh, what a pleasure it is to see my lifetime of accomplishment summed up in a 3-minute film. My best years are behind me. So much left undone. So little time.
Funny, funny stuff.
My life is over.
No, it isn't. You have another 10 years left.
Leela! He could live another 100 years!
No, he couldn't. When you turn 160, robots from the Sunset Squad take you to a mysterious planet and you never return.
Wow, a whole planet of old people. Where is it?
[spookily] Nobody knows!
So many loves half-loved, so many inventions half-invented. That damn time machine alone set me back 15 years.
If only it'd worked, you could go back and not waste your time on it.
There's no one to carry on after I'm gone. No one to take care of my work and my research and my fabulous fortune. [He gasps.] By God, that's it! I've got to name a successor.
A successor?
A successor to the Professor?
There's no time to lose. I'm off to my lab to build a successor-naming machine!
Man, the Professor's been in his lab for days.
I hope he didn't die. Unless he left a note naming me his successor. Then I hope he did die.
You? The successor? Over my empty shell! The Professor will pick me. Only I have his lobster-like tenacity.
Up yours, Zoidberg. Up wherever your species traditionally crams things. The only sensible way to choose a successor is with a limbo contest.
What?
Kingston rules. Two men go down, one come up.
Look, the Professor trusts me with a giant spaceship. He wouldn't trust the rest of you with his dentures.
Yesh, he would.
Sorry, everyone, but need I remind you? Blood is thicker than water.
[writing] Blood ... thicker ... water.
Everyone, I have a very dramatic announcement. So anyone with a weak heart should leave now. Goodbye.
Uh, Professor?
Oh, oh, yes, the announcement! As you all know, I am not long for this world.
Yes, we know.
True, mon.
Buh!
One foot in the grave.

So I've picked my successor. It's someone in whom I have great faith -- even though his mind is undeveloped and he's accomplished nothing. [Fry flexes his fingers and chuckles.] My closest living relative.
Oh, yeah!
My clone, Cubert Farnsworth.
He's horrible!
Crud. Can I at least be in charge of your dentures?
You wish!
Where did Cubert come from?
12 years ago I began the cloning process by removing some skin cells from one of the shapelier growths on my back.
Wait. If he's your clone, why doesn't his nose look like yours?
I left him in his first tube too long and he got squished up against the side.
Is he dumb or just ugly?
Let's find out.
What? You've never seen a genius's wiener before?
No.
Never.
Well, once in the park.
Mmm!
As long as I'm going to be in charge here, let me examine my so-called "crew", if it can so be called. First of all, Dr. Zoidberg, do you even have a medical degree?
I lost it ... in a volcano.
And why do we need a bending robot around here anyway? What possible use do we have for you?
Uh ... me no speaka the English.
And why does our space pilot have only one eye? There's someone I'd like you to meet. His name is depth perception!
Why, you little--
Wow, that hurt -- the air!
Im pending para un bending!
Oh, Cubert, come in here. I have something amazing to show you.
What is it? A competent employee? I doubt that very much!
Little twerp.
Aye, Chihuahua!
As my successor, I'm trusting you to carry on my work. These are just some of the half-finished inventions you'll spend your life finishing.
I didn't realise you were the inventor of the junk heap.

That's my prize-winning Smellescope. If a dog craps anywhere in the universe, you can bet I won't be out of the loop. [He points at a green machine with an oscilloscope built into it.] And this is my universal translator. Unfortunately so far it only translates into an incomprehensible dead language.
Hello.
Bonjour!
Crazy gibberish!
Don't you have any worthwhile inventions?
Why, certainly. Step over here.
These are the dark matter engines I invented. They allow my starship to travel between galaxies in mere hours.
That's impossible. You can't go faster than the speed of light.
Of course not. That's why scientists increased the speed of light in 2208.
Also impossible.
And what makes my engines truly remarkable is the afterburner which delivers 200% fuel efficiency.
That's especially impossible.
Not at all. It's very simple.
Then explain it.
Now that's impossible. It came to me in a dream and I forgot it in another dream.
Your explanations are pure weapons-grade bolog-nium. It's all impossible.
Nothing is impossible. Not if you can imagine it. That's what being is a scientist is all about.
No, that's what being a magical elf is all about.
Oh, my God! Oh, my God! It's Elzar, the TV chef! Oh, kill me now, people!
How we doing here?
Oh, Elzar, everything's so good!
What are you, an ass-kissing machine?
Yes, sir! Good one, sir!
Oh, it's a gem of an evening. I feel so wonderful having someone to take over my life's work. And it's all thanks to Cubert.
Look, Professor, I may be identical to you in every possible way but that doesn't mean I'm anything like you.
You ... wha?
I don't wanna be an inventor. I wanna be something useful like a teacher's aide or a prison guard or a science-fiction cartoon writer.
But-But what about my hopes and my dreams and my wonderful inventions?
In your entire life your only half-decent invention was me and I didn't turn out like you wanted either.
You folks still doing alright?
Oh, yes, Elzar.
Good, 'cause it turns out I forgot to cook that chicken.

Bad news, everyone. By the time you watch this tape, I'll be gone, leaving behind me nothing but a history of failure and my original hip-bones. You see, I've been lying about my age; I'm not actually 150, I'm 160. Oh, vanity, thy name is Professor Farnsworth. And now that I have nothing to live for, I've alerted the Sunset Squad robots to take me away.

Goodbye, cruel world. [He stops walking.] Goodbye, cruel lamp. [He stops again by the window.] Goodbye, cruel velvet drapes, lined with what would appear to be some sort of cruel muslin ... [The Reaperbot growls.] ... and the cute little pom-pom curtain pull cords, cruel though they may be a--
[on holo-recorder] And now that I've nothing to live for, I've alerted the Sunset Squad robots to take me away.
What?
Oh, no!
Oh.
[on holo-recorder] I know you're all very upset, especially Bender.
Well, life goes on. Except for you!
[on holo-recorder] I'm sure that Bender has just made a cutting remark, but he doesn't know I taped over his soap operas to record this message.
You bastard!
We've gotta get him back.
Impossible! No one knows where they take those old geezers.
Nothing is impossible. You'd know that if you really took after the Professor, like I do.
You're his uncle, dummy. He takes after you.
Uh ... what?
Wait a second. That means I also take after you!
Quiet. I think I know how to find the Professor.
Lay it on us, big boots.
If the Smellescope can pick up the Professor's odour, we may have a chance to save him.
I think not. As you probably already don't know, odours are made up of particles that can't travel through the vacuum of space.
I'm zeroing in on him. [She sniffs.] BENGAY ... mothballs ... [She sniffs again.] ... letters to the editor. It's the Professor!
To the flying machine!
To the left! [He sniffs again and moves slightly.] No, to the up! [And some more.] U-turn! U-turn!
We'll never find this place. Robots are very good at keeping secrets.
No, we're not, you little bed-wetter. Oops! I'm sorry.
There it is! The Near-Death Star!
OK, we'll tell them the Professor escaped and we're bringing him back. Fry, you'll have to dress up like a 160-year-old man.
I'm on it!
[sarcastic] My God, the illusion is so perfect I almost forgot I was looking at an idiot!
Now, they may ask for a DNA sample.
I'd like to see them find it!
This plan is impossible. We don't even have a sample of the Professor's DNA.
I think I know where to get some.
Why do I have to be the hump?
'Cause you're too ugly to be a wart.
Your Medicare dollars at work.
Halt! Identify this guest.
Uh, this is Professor Hubert Farnsworth. He escaped.
Escaped? No one escapes.
This guest does not look 160.
What? I'm old. Listen  [old man voice] Hey, you kids, get off the lawn!
Hmm, it is true old people are often concerned that there are children on their lawns.
There's no denying that. But we'll still need to verify his identity with a DNA sample.
Got a hot, steaming batch right here!
We only needed one cell!
Eh, keep the change, buddy.
Stupid robot.
Did your hump just say something?
Uh ... I-I've got talking hump syndrome.
Ah, T.H.S.
Identity confirmed. Return this shambling shuffle-boarder to his room.
7152 Maple Drive.
Sounds nice.
Prepare to be surprised.
So this is where they stick old people. It's horrific!
At least it keeps them from driving.
Brace yourself for the worst.
And yet he looks so natural.
What's happening?
He's hooked up to a life-support system. [She pulls a tube off.] We have to disconnect him very, very carefully, or the shock could kill him.

Freeze! [Leela pulls Farnsworth away from the tubes in one go and accelerates the hover-ship away from the guardbot. He chases them around the side of the gravestone and five other guardbots give chase.] Seize them!
Seize them!
Seize them!
Seize them!
Get them-- I mean seize them!
Aww, I'm so bad at this!
Uh-oh!
We're probably gonna make it, but we might not.
It's impossible! We'll never fit.
Will too!
Told you.
Come on, Leela! Step your big boot down on the gas pedal.
They've blown out one of our engines!
[fast] Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it! Fix it!
Only the Professor knows how to fix it. We have to wake him up.
Try shocking him.
[shouting] Your social security cheque is late! Stuff costs more than it used to! Young people use curse words!
Damnit, we'll have to fix the engine ourself.
We can't, you bastard! No one knows how it works. It's impossible!

Nothing is impossible. I understand how the engines work now. It came to me in a dream. [He lifts an access hatch and starts fiddling with some wires under the floor.] The engines don't move the ship at all. The ship stays where it is and the engines move the universe around it.
That's a complete load.
Nothing's a complete load. Not if you can imagine it. That's what being a scientist is all about. Right, Professor? [Farnsworth mumbles. Cubert closes the access panel.] Let's ride!
Good news, everyone! He's made a complete recovery.
Yeah!
Wow!
All right!
I'm as spry as a 140-year-old. [He jumps and something cracks.] See? I only broke one ankle.
So what were they doing to you in that awful drawer?
Oh, they had me hooked up to a bizarre virtual world that seemed absolutely real.
What was it like?
It was as though I were living in a facility in Florida with hundreds of other old people. All day long we'd play bingo, eat oatmeal and wait for our children to call.
It's a hundred times more horrible than anything I could imagine.
Oh, my, yes. Thank you all for saving me. Especially you, my little clone. No matter what you decide to do with your life, I'm still proud of you.
I've already decided. Dad, when I grow up I wanna be just like you.
Don't worry, son, you will. Incidentally, you might want to read up on a condition known as "wandering bladder".
Why?
No reason. No reason at all.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Finally, the last form of the day. Welcome to Stampy Town. Population, five! [He stamps the form five times then puts it on top of a pile of other forms. He picks up the pile and staples it together.] And now for the finishing touch. [He puts the pile through a shredder and it comes out as mulch, which is recycled into blank sheets of paper. A robotic arm lifts the paper into the in-tray.] Ah, the cycle of bureaucracy. [A red tube comes down a message tube and lands in a tray.] Sweet gorilla of Manila! A letter from the Central Bureaucracy! [He takes a piece of paper out of the red tube.] [reading] Attention, Hermes Conrad  You are about to receive a letter from the Central Bureaucracy. [Another red tube appears and Hermes takes a piece of paper out of.] My God! It's from the Central Bureaucracy!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm having a poker game tonight with some friends from my old cryogenics job. You guys interested?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I don't know. I only gamble with chumps.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'll play.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm in!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Leela, Fry, robot. No matter what it is you're doing tonight, I'm available.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: We're playing poker. But I'm warning you, my friends are serious players.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Bah, big shots. I say let the dice do the talking.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Wow! You look happy. Is someone fired?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Better! The Central Bureaucracy is conducting an inspection tomorrow. I will finally be promoted to grade 35, the 35th highest grade there is.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hermes, wait! We're having a poker party. Stay and whip off a batch of your famous jerk dip.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Sorry, I spent all day putting my office in order. Now I got to go home and relax the traditional Jamaican way  A glass of warm milk and good night sleep.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Jamaican? I thought you were some kinda outer-space potato man.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Ah, that must be my old boss.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hello, Leela. You're fired.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I know.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm sorry but it's just that you're over a year late for work at this point.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [dramatically] Let the games begin!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: So I told Leela, "Your request for a date is most flattering but I must decline." These office romances never work out. After all, that is how I met my horrible wife.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: But you never wore your ring. I didn't know you had a wife.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: And my wife doesn't know I have a job. I keep my personal and professional lives separate.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Come on, let's deal. You'll have plenty of time to talk when you're poor.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: What's with the specs, Bender?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: They're my lucky shades. I stole them off some lucky guy while his lucky seeing eye dog was taking a whiz.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hey!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I can't spell anything with these cards.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Finally, I have a good claw. See? [He turns his cards around.] Three human females, a number and a king giving himself brain surgery.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: It doesn't matter how many human females you have, Bender's on a hot streak.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Uh, what can I say? Must be my lucky shades! [He taps his shades and they suddenly change to X-Ray specs. He looks at the cards around the table.] Nothing, nothing, crap, crap, garbage. [He lays his cards out on the table.] Read 'em and leak salt water!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, man!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's my baby's milk money!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, I am broke. What will I tell my horrible wife?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: If I were you I'd be more worried about that tapeworm going to town on your intestines.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [suspicious] Let me see those glasses.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Um ... uh...

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, my various Gods! X-Ray specs!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Guys, I swear those are prescription. I need 'em for reading stuff ... on the other side of stuff.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Cheater!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Get him!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Break his neck!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No, don't hurt him! He's my best friend!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [from inside] Hey, you wouldn't hit a guy with X-Ray glasses would you? [Beating sounds come from inside.] Ow! Easy on the arm! Oh! Oh, my ass!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Great cow of Moscow!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Uh, it was ghosts! Big ones! And a tornado!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh! I'll never pass inspection now. They'll bust me lower than a limbo stick ... at carnival time. [Fry and Leela poke their heads around the door.] [crying] And that's as low as limbo sticks get.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Aw, hey, c'mon, don't worry. We'll watch you clean up.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: It's too late. The inspector will be here in exactly one second.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Who the hell are you?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Morgan Proctor, bureaucrat grade 19.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hermes Conrad, bureaucrat grade 36.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Enough friendly banter. Shall we begin the inspection?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: This way, please.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering] Jeez, Hermes, you seem awfully calm about this.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering] Don't worry. I have a plan.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] I'm going to jump!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] No!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] No!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Do a flip!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Don't do it, Hermes! You have so much to live for.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering; to Leela] I get it, reverse psychology.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Please, old friend, don't jump. Use another method that won't damage your liver. Other people need it, you know.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Husband! Nooo!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Outta my way, wife! I wasn't cut out to be a bureaucrat anyway. I'm only anal 78.36% of the time. I'm not worthy to stamp a form, so I'll stamp the pavement with my flabby body.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Bureaucrat Conrad, if you complete your death transaction without filing a suicide and/or falling accident permit, you will be posthumously demoted.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Life. Death. Either way I'm demoted to a tiny cubicle.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Sweet something of ... of someplace.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: As your superior, I hereby relieve you of duty. Consider yourself on paid vacation.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh! The ultimate penalty!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I recommend the health cure on Spa 5, the sauna planet. Here, read.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Spa 5? Is it good?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, it's wonderful! I don't know anything about it but they give me a bucket of krill for every patient I send.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Naturally I'll have to assign a bureaucrat to fill in for Hermes while he's away. I assign me, I accept. Welcome aboard.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Then it's settled. Hermes will relax and Zoidberg will eat. Hurrah!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I've been reviewing your corporate records. Regarding last Monday's delivery, why did it take twice as long as scheduled?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Fry got his head stuck in a crater.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [ashamed] I thought it would fit.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [to Bender] And during this period of head-crater interaction, what were you doing?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Martini drinking contests with the autopilot. I would've had him this time but we ran out of olives.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I can explain--

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You really think you can explain how you left port without a full compliment of olives? I think not.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering] What is this, high school?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Locker check!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Why isn't this jacket in alphabetical order?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: What?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: The zipper. It should be at the bottom.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [ashamed] Hey, sometimes a guy gets lonely.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I-- I've never seen anything like this. [She picks up the cap.] Why is there yoghurt in this cap?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Uh, I can explain that. See, it used to be milk and, well, time makes fools of us all.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You are all dismissed. Fry, I will speak to you alone.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Uh, wait, this is the other Fry's locker. I'm "Phry" with a P-H.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [taking off her glasses.] Admit it, Fry  You're a slob. [She kisses him.] A dirty, filthy slob. [She kisses him again.] Dirty boy! Dirty! Dirty! Dirty!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: What the hell's going on? I thought you were anti-dirty not pro-dirty.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm surrounded by neat freaks everyday. There's nothing kinkier to me than a filthy slop-jock like you.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [bashful] Oh, stop!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Now listen, you filthy pig. No one can know about us. If anyone asks, I'll deny it.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Just like very other girl I've dated.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: And two and three and four and ... [She point a huge laser at them.] ... come on, work those arms!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering] This is no spa, it's a forced-labour camp.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Curse that Dr. Zoidberg! If I get out of here, he'll be looking down the business-end of a shrimp fork.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Give him one for me too, mate. I don't know why I go to him.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I don't miss twice, campers!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: And for those six and a half reasons, I am demoting Leela to co-pilot.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Co-pilot? Under who?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: The autopilot.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That drunk?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Mr. Bender, you are now in charge of co-ordinating the Professor's bodily functions.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's a full-time job.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: And Fry, as for you, I am promoting you to executive delivery boy. You will no longer go on deliveries and you will have your own office next to mine.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Alright!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Mr. Bender, would you high-five him so we can continue this meeting? [Bender reluctantly does.] And on the rebound? [Bender kicks Fry in his left shin and Fry screams.] Meeting adjourned.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I can't figure why she's so nice to you, Fry.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: She's a hateful monster, this Morgan. She scolded and hit me. I tell you, she's risking my friendship with her.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Bender, what happened to you?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Morgan made me walk the Professor. There we were in the park when suddenly some old lady says I stole her purse. I chucked the Professor at her but she kept coming. So I had to hit her with this purse I found. Ah, the point is, it's Morgan's fault. That pencil-pushing scazwag. [Leela gestures him to shut up.] Why, if she were here, I'd-- Uh-oh, is she behind me?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No. I'm in front of you.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Morgan? It's 3am.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I know. A skunk knocked over my garbage and suddenly all I could think of was you. [She looks around the messy apartment.] My God! It's so ... repulsive. [She looks at something covered with a sheet and food.] So, uh, this is where you eat?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Eat and sleep.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, Fry!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Uh, wait, Bender's my roommate. He could be back any second.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Not likely. I ordered him to flush out the Professor's ear wax.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hey, Fry, I made you a candle with-- [He gasps.] What the--? [He zooms in. Morgan is in bed with Fry. She holds the sheets up around her. Fry pulls the sheets up around him.] Oh, now I see! Now I get it. Now the pieces are falling into place  The office, the promotion, that dwarf in my book club who steals my opinions. [Morgan runs out with the sheets wrapped around her.] It's all coming together now!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I must say, this opens my eyes. Another case closed, my dear Watson.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [shouting] Morgan, come back! He's stuck in a loop.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: For I was blind but now I see!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [from inside] The cat's out of the bag now!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Mr. Bender, about last night  That was just a ... a misunderstanding.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, you didn't understand? Well let me explain. You ... [He points at Fry.] ... were having sex with you.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No. You see, a bureaucrat of my rank isn't supposed to fraternise.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's what makes it so juicy. It's the forbidden fruit angle everybody loves. First I'll say "You'll never guess who saw Fry and Morgan doing it," and they'll say "Who, Bender? Who?" and I'll say "It was lovable ... [His voice begins to slow down.] ... old Bender."

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hey, what did you do to him?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I downloaded his brain. Everything that is Bender is right here. His mind, his memories, his in-your-face interface.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [mechanical voice] I am Bender. Please insert girder.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: But, but ... Bender need brain ... for ... smart making. [Morgan puts the disk in a red tube and sends it away.] What did you do now? Stop doing things!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I sent the disk to be filed at the Central Bureaucracy. I did what I had to do, Fry; He was a bad robot.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No, he was a bad friend. I want him back right now.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Then you should have filed a request 20 years ago.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm sick of you and your bureaucracy!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Dirty boy! Dirty boy!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You and Morgan were having an affair?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I couldn't help it. She loved me because of the part of me that's a slob and I loved her because of the part of me that's desperate.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [mechanical voice] I am Bender. Please insert girder.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Poor Bender. Without his brain he's become all quiet and helpful. We've got to go to the Central Bureaucracy and get that disk back!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Yeah!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, yes, we must, yes.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Why?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Well, those arguments aside, we're still going.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You can't just waltz into the Central Bureaucracy. It's a tangled web of red tape and regulations. I've never been but a friend of mine went completely mad trying to find the washroom there.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Then we'll need a guide. Someone who's been there before.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, I've been there. Lots of times!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Look at that  The carts go out full but they come in empty. It's criminally inefficient.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [whispering] Quiet, mate. Pulling the empty carts is the closest thing we get to sleep.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: But don't you see? They could increase efficiency 4% if they used the empty carts to bring in heavy mining machinery.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Hey, I like the way you think.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, Lord!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You know, you oughta be a bureaucrat or something.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Man, how long is this gonna take?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm still waiting on my birth certificate.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Well, it doesn't look like I'll make it inside with the rest of you. Uh, but good luck. Just leave me where I drop.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, great! Someone had a baby.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Come on. I have a better idea.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Excuse me? We're from the Planet Express delivery company. We're here to deliver a robot.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [mechanical voice] I am Bender. Please insert girder.

Line: Looks like we've got a new office cut-up!

Line: Look out! Look out! I'm gonna crash my slow-mobile! I had to swerve to avoid you.

Line: While you're crashing, could you tell us where all these canisters end up?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Oh, you want Central Filing.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: OK.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: OK.

Line: OK, thanks.

Line: Wonderful.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [screaming] Nooo!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Central Filing? Of course I know where that is. I'm a grade 20.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Where is it?

Line: I can't tell you. What do I look like? A grade 16?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: We're getting nowhere slowly. Here, I'll address this to the Central Filing room. [She takes something of her wrist machine and puts it in the tube.] Then we'll track it using my wrist LoJack-a-mater.

Line: Cold. Cold. Warmer. Hot, hot, hot, hot, hot, hot.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Please don't tell my supervisor I was sleeping.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: This is it. We'll just run in, grab Bender's disk and run out. Got it?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: We'll never find that disk will we, Bender?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [mechanical voice] I am Bender. Please insert girder.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You're right. Nothing is over as long as there's one thin ray of hope.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Lost something? [She rides a slow-mobile towards them.] I should have known you'd come here rather than follow proper procedure. And I did know. And that's why I came here.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Listen, Morgan, we're through. You're an evil, heartless woman and I never wanna see you again. However, would you help us get Bender back for old time's sake?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: I'm afraid he's lost in the master in pile, and it would take some sort of giant, mechanical, atomic-powered sorting machine to find him.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You rang?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Damnit, Hermes, just jump already. Stop hogging that healthy liver.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No, I want to live. Organising that forced-labour spa rekindled my lifelong love of bureaucracy.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: My Hermes got that hellhole running so efficiently that all the physical labour is now done by a single Australian man.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: But how did you know we were here?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Dr. Zoidberg brought us.

Line: It was me! I'm the hero!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Number 1.0.

Line: Number 1.0, I hereby petition you for an emergency sort-and-file, under regulation 2 point--

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [waggling his finger] D-D-D-D-Don't quote me regulations. I co-chaired the committee that reviewed the recommendation to revise the colour of the book that regulation's in. We kept it grey.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Sir, please, I must located the disk with my friend's brain on it.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Very well. But your bureaucratic licence will be revoked if you fail to sort the master in pile by closing time  1pm.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's only four minutes from now.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Requisition me a beat.

Character: Born to be all obsessive and snotty,"

Character: I made my friends and relations file long applications,

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Character: To get into my 10th birthday party.

Line: [singing] But something changed when my man turned pro.

Line: [singing] I was sortin' but I wasn't smilin'.

Line: [singing] He forgot that it's not about badges and ranks.

Line: I'm Bender, baby! Please insert liquor!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Yeah!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Congratulations.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Congratulations indeed but you finished with one second to spare so I'm demoting you. A good bureaucrat never finishes early.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's OK, Hermes. At least we have you back.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Not yet you don't. I'm still acting bureaucrat of Planet Express. And I have some changes to make. First, Fry, you're fired. Second--

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Not so fast! While I was sorting I came upon a certain document filed by one Morgan Proctor. Form B  Notification of Romantic Entanglement.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That's right, she fraternised me!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: That form isn't about you. It refers to my high school prom date. It was a regulation date that ended in regulation disappointment.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Yes, but you only stamped it four times!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: No! No! I was young and reckless.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Bureaucrat Conrad, you are technically correct -- the best kind of correct. I hereby promote you to grade 37. [He changes Hermes' badge to 37. He points at Morgan.] And as for you. [shouting] Guards! [Guards surround Morgan.] [talking] Bring me the forms I need to fill out to have her taken away!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Well, it looks like I'll be needing my heroic bureaucrat back. At severely-reduced pay, of course.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: It's better than nothing.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: What about me? Can I come back at severely-reduced pay?

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: You got it, mon! In fact, severely-reduced pay all around! [The staff cheer and Hermes hops on a slow-mobile.] Come on, wife, let's blow this joint!

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: Now it's time for my song! [singing] When I was two, there was a tidal wave in--

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back
Line: [over credits] Aw.

Episode: How Hermes Requisitioned His Groove Back

Line: Exciting news, people! The pet licence I requisitioned for Nibbler has arrived.
Hermes, that's sweet. I didn't know you cared about Nibbler.

Dream on, woman. I'd like to put the little bastard in a sack and toss the sack in a river and hurl the river into space. But I do like filling out requisitions and these were some doozies! [He opens the envelope.] Great Jah's dreadlocks! There's been a mix-up. This isn't a pet licence, it's a fishing licence. And it's mandatory!
Ah! The exact centre of the Atlantic Ocean. This seems the logical place for fish to congregate.
So we're in international waters?
Indeed so.

Falcon, this is Blue Raven, the goose has nested. Repeat, the goose has nested. [A speedboat pulls up next to the ship and a man hands Bender a package which he puts in his chest cabinet. The speedboat pulls away and Bender turns to Fry and Farnsworth who haven't noticed anything.] Hey, guess what you're accessories to?
The sun, the sea air, good friends.
Leela's right, fishing blows. Whattya say we make it interesting?
Why not?
Yeah.
Yeah, cool.
Everybody kick in five bucks. [Everyone except Zoidberg hands him $5.] There, wasn't that interesting?
Bender!
This contest is as good as over. I once caught a fish this big.
Oh, yeah? I once caught a fish this big!
I'm afraid you're both out of your league, boys, 'cause you're looking at a woman who owns her own harpoon.
Harpoon, my ass!
OK.
Let's see now, which bait to use? [Zoidberg looks up.] Crickets? Squid? Chicken necks?

Excuse me, if I might be so bold, I'm willing to offer my services as a bait critic. [He eats a sardine.] These sardines for example are bland and tasteless. [He eats a few more.] And these dry, stringy night crawlers, though juicy ... [He eats a few.] ... very, very juicy--
I don't believe this! It's eating my bait! [He picks up his fishing rod and hits Zoidberg with it.] Beat it, you mooching crawdad!
Hey, Fry, check out my laser-guided fishing rod.
[whispering] Quiet, Bender, you're scaring away the fish.
Fine. I'll head over to the other side. [He leans over the side of the ship.] [shouting] Good luck fishing on this side!
I can hit a fish between the eyes from 20 yards!
Oh, yeah? I can hit a shrimp!
A shrimp? [Bender's laser guide appears between Fry's eyes.] I find it a bit hard to believe that--
Aha! [She throws the harpoon and starts pulling it in.] Gather round, chumps! I got the winner!
Oh, so this is where you shop for your boots?
Couple more of those and you'll have yourself a fish stick!

Hey, a fish this fine belongs in a fish nugget-style chunklet. And anyway, it's bigger than anything you've caught. [He laughs and bends over. Bender hits him with his fishing rod again.] Ow! My small intestine!
Bingo! Whatever it is, it's 20 times heavier than a boot.

You'll never catch anything with that primitive technology. What you need is this fish pheromone. [He pulls out a spray can.] The most potent aphrodisiac known to fishkind. [He shakes the can and tries to spray it on his line but he is holding it the wrong way so it sprays back in his face.] Uh-oh!
[sexfully] I'm so into you!
Oh, my!
[shouting] Hey, Bender, I just caught a fish this big!

Quit exaggerating, Fry. Ah, screw this! [He throws his fishing rod in the bin.] If I'm not gonna catch a fish, I might as well not catch a big fish. [He takes Amy's parasol and bends it to make a giant fish hook.] There. Like most of life's problems this one can be solved with bending.
Bender, be careful. That's the ship's diamond filament tether. It's unbreakable.
Then why do I have to be careful?
It belonged to my grandmother.
My Manwich!
Wake up, everyone! I've got something. And this time it's alive! [She pulls out another boot with Zoidberg on the end of it and groans.] Dr. Zoidberg, since when do you even wear boots?
I wasn't wearing it. [ashamed] I was eating it.
Come on, let's go home.
Sunburn! My fabulous body! It's ruined! What happened to my parasol?
I don't know. It wasn't here when I took your umbrella. [Amy growls.] What? I put sunblock on you.
Well it didn't work!
Come on, Bender. Pull in your line and let's go.
Hey, I'm snagged.
It's not snagged, the mechano man has caught something! [Bender struggles to pull in the line. A huge shadow looms towards the ship from the water.] Sweet Zombie Jesus! It's huge!
It's coming up!
Oh, that's big!
A colossal-mouth bass!
It's diving!
It's pulling us under! Everyone into the ship!
Wait! I'll save us! By cutting the unbreakable diamond filament! [He snips at the tether with his claw but it doesn't break.] Well, at least I'll die with my friends. Hello?
[from ship] My Speedos!
Depth at 45 hundred feet, 48 hundred, 50 hundred! 5000 feet!
Dear Lord, that's over 150 atmospheres of pressure.
How many atmospheres can this ship withstand?
Well it's a spaceship, so I'd say anywhere between zero and one.
What's that? Is someone bending girders?
We'll be crushed if we don't equalise the pressure.
How do we do that?
That should do it.
We're all gonna die!
Wait, I'll be back in a minute.
You did it, Fry!
Did what?
People, it's far, far worse than we thought; my fish got away.
There. Good as new! Except we're three miles below the surface, we don't have any food and the ship won't work underwater.
[restrained] Tempers are wearing thin. Let's just hope some robot doesn't kill everybody.

The important thing is that we don't panic. There are rules for situations like this. [He holds up the Code of Conduct for Cannibalism book.] Now, the first order of business is lunch. I suggest a nice lobster Zoidberg-- I mean lobster Newburg-- I mean Doctor Zoidberg.
OK, everyone, calm down. The Professor and I will get to work on the ship. Bender, Zoidberg, since you can survive underwater, you'll go out and look for food.
I'd better go too. They don't know what I like.
Fry, no! The pressure will crush you like a green snake under a sugar cane truck.
Not necessarily. This is chance for Fry to test out my experimental anti-pressure pill.
I can't swallow that.
Well then good news! It's a suppository.
How are you doing there, Fry? [Fry blubbers.] Glad to hear it. [He picks up another fish.] Aha!
Aw, yeah!

Yum, yum, yum! [He eats it, not realising it is the top of a large pilot fish.] Uh-oh! [The fish chases him and Zoidberg woops and hides in a shell. The fish passes him and he scuttles back to Fry and Bender with the shell on his back.] Look at me, I'm Dr. Zoidberg, homeowner!
Careful, Fry, I think that flag might be poisonous.

Ahoy, mateys! I shanghaied us some hearty grog. [He opens the bottle and tries to drink what is in it but the liquid just drips out and trails away from him in the ocean current.] Arr! The laws o' science be a harsh mistress!
Say, robot, old buddy? Could you help me move a couch?
Uh, OK, but I'm not carrying it upstairs.
What is it, Fry?
[blubbering] I think I saw a mermaid.
You want some lemonade? You saw a big parade?
Your student loans have been repaid? Then how 'bout lending your old pal Zoidberg a few bucks, Mr. Millionaire!
Fry, swallow your food. Then talk.
A mermaid!
You think you saw a mermaid?
No, I did see a mermaid! She was wearing a tube top and she had a beautiful scaly tail. And I think she had hair extensions.
Yeah, right!
Sure she did.
OK, Fry!
You're simply hallucinating, you ... moron.
What's so far-fetched about mermaids? I mean, there's all sorts of weird sea creatures here in the future. Like Dr. Zoidberg.
I'm afraid Fry is suffering from ocean madness.

Every time something good happens to me you say it's some kind of madness, or I'm drunk, or I ate too much candy. Well I saw a real mermaid and I wish for once my friends would have decency and kindness to believe me.
[whispering] Ocean madness.
He may have ocean madness but that's no excuse for ocean rudeness.

[muttering] Ocean madness. Yeah, right. It's always something, ain't it? [The mermaid knocks on the window and Fry gasps.] [talking] It's her! Bender, wake up! She's here! Wake up! [Bender turns up the volume on himself and snores louder. The mermaid beckons Fry. He heads for the door then remembers something.] Oh! oxygen!
Here you go, darlin'.
Hey! I can breath and talk, just like a fish!
Oh, you speak fish?
What?
I'm sorry, my accent's atrocious. Hi, my name's Umbriel!
I'm Fry. So, uh, am I gonna drown?
Course not. Just stay calm and let the currents relax your every muscle.
Aw, yeah!
Did it just get warmer?
I can't believe you're really real. I like your tail.
Oh, you're sweet. I like those wiggly doo-dads comin' outta your hips.
Oh, thanks. They're called pants.
This here's a volcanic vent. The water comes out at over 4000 degrees.
No kidding.
